lines.text: Hold up your right hand. Do you solemnly swear to uphold... oh, this is ridiculous. You're deputized. Grab some gear, I'll get the horses.
Wait a minute, don't I get to wear a tin star?
Not on your life!
Want a gun hand?
You? No, thanks.
I do handle them pretty well. The only trouble is, those best able to testify to my aim aren't around for comment.
All gunfighters are lonely. They live in fear. They die without a dime, a woman or a friend.

[hears banging on her door]
Who is it?
Open the door!

[breaks the door open]
Start talking, Kate.
Doc, I don't know nothin' about it.
TALK.

Why? What difference does it make now? I sure messed everything up real good, ain't I? I wanted you back... because I love you. And... I... I thought if Wyatt was out of the way, you'd come back to me. That's why I kept quiet when I heard them.
[breaking down]
I must've been out of my mind.
Where?
The Clanton ranch.
Who was there?

[getting emotional]
I didn't want that boy to be killed.

[losing patients]
Who was there?
Ike, Finn, Cotton Wilson, and the MacLowerys.
And Ringo?
[Kate doesn't answer]

[enraged]
WAS RINGO THERE?

[to Billy Clanton]
You think you're pretty tough, don't ya, son? I never knew a gunslinger yet so tough he lived to celebrate his 35th birthday. I learned one rule about gunslingers. There's always a man faster on the draw than you are, and the more you use a gun, the sooner you're gonna run into that man.
Look, Holliday, as long as I'm the law here, not one of those cowpokes is going to cross that deadline with a gun. I don't care if his name *is* Shanghai Pierce.
Well spoken. I'll repeat those words at your funeral.
I'm a gambler. Money's just a tool of my trade.
Of course, you will guarantee you won't lose.
I never lose. You see, poker's played by desperate men who cherish money. I don't lose because I have nothing to lose, including my life.
I don't know why I get into gunfights. I guess sometimes I just get lonely.

[after shooting a few antagonists]
Anybody else want to try their luck?

[Herding the arrested cowboys to jail]
Get moving! - Keep moving, all of ya!

[Holding his wounded arm]
All right, Doc.
[In a threatening tone]
We ain't finished yet!
You would have been, but I felt in a charitable mood tonight.
What difference does it make to you where I go or who I take up with?
Shut up!

[throwing her dress on the floor]
Get your things together. You're leaving!

[entering from the bedroom]
She's staying here!
Keep out of this, Ringo!
You got no right to come bustin' in here!
I'm talking to Kate. Take a walk!
Anything you got to say you can say in front of him.

[with contempt]
You slut!
Wait a minute, Holliday. You don't talk to my woman like that!

[contemptuously]
Your woman? Anybody's woman!
There's $20,000 in it for you - cash!
$20,000! The wages of sin are rising!
$20,00 against a six foot hole in Boot Hill or a $20 a month pension - IF you live long enough to collect it.
We'd like you to come to the wedding, Doc, - if it doesn't interfere with your poker.
I'm not good at weddings - only funerals. Deal me out.
If I'm going to die, atr least let me die with the only friend I've ever had!
Awful quiet. Too quiet.

[after losing consecutive hands of blackjack]
You know Doc, if we were playing for real, I might be compelled to take a look at that deck
I might be compelled to make you.

[Charlie goes for his gun; Doc draws first and offers it to Charlie]
Here, take mine.

[Handling Doc's gun]
It's a good thing Wyatt doesn't let us draw these; somebody might get hurt.

[wanting to leave before the gunfight]
Ike, I can't take this kind of gunplay anymore. Let me out.

[angrily]
Get over there.

[sees Cotton trying to ride away when shooting starts]
Cotton! You chicken-livered miserable... !
There's a stage for Abilene in the morning. I want you to be on it.
Can't. The marshal of Abilene sent me here.
I Like you, Wyatt Earp. I like your cut.
no knives, no guns and no killings.
No knives, no guns, no killings.
That's it.
You have my word as a gentleman.
